rows.name: text_top_1
rows.value:
An excellent thing to practice when you are travelling and have time on your hands is to recite the prime factorizations for the numbers in order. This also provides practice with talking about powers. Knowing prime factorizations with ease will be helpful in many things to come, such as working with fractions. Have fun with this and donâ€™t push your child beyond their comfort level.

It goes like this: 
1 is a unit, 
2 is a prime, 
3 is a prime, 
4 is 2 squared, 
5 is a prime, 
6 is 2 x 3, 
7 is a prime, 
8 is 2 cubed, 
9 is 3 squared, 
10 is 2 x 5, 
11 is a prime, 
12 is 2 squared x 3, 
13 is a prime, 
14 is 2 x 7, 
15 is 3 x 5,
16 is 2 to the fourth. 

If your child stumbles, help them figure it out rather than simply reminding them of the answer.
